title.text: Detecting Latent Ideology in Expert Text: Evidence From Academic Papers in Economics

abstractContent.text: Previous work on extracting ideology from text has focused on domains where expression of political views is expected, but it's unclear if current technology can work in domains where displays of ideology are considered inappropriate.
We present a supervised ensemble n-gram model for ideology extraction with topic adjustments and apply it to one such domain: research papers written by academic economists.
We show economists' political leanings can be correctly predicted, that our predictions generalize to new domains , and that they correlate with public policy-relevant research findings.
We also present evidence that unsupervised models can under-perform in domains where ideological expression is discouraged.

introductionContent.text: Recent advances in text mining demonstrate that political ideology can be predicted from textoften with great accuracy.
Standard experimental settings in this literature are ones where ideology is explicit, such as speeches by American politicians or editorials by authors.
An open question is whether ideology can be detected in arenas where it is strongly discouraged.
A further consideration for applied researchers is whether these tools can offer insight into questions of import for policymakers.
To address both of these issues, we examine one such domain that is both policy-relevant and where ideology is not overtly expressed: research papers written by academic economists.
Economic ideas are important for shaping policy by influencing the public debate and setting the range of expert opinion on various policy options.
Economics also views itself as a science carefully applying rigorous methodologies and using institutionalized safe-guards such as peer review.
The field's most prominent research organization explicitly prohibits researchers from making policy recommendations in papers that it releases (National Bureau of.
Despite these measures, economics' close proximity to public policy decisions have led many to see it as being driven by ideology.
Does this view of partisan economics have any empirical basis?
To answer the question of whether economics is politicized or neutral, we present a supervised ensemble n-gram model of ideology extraction with topic adjustments.
1 Our methodology is most closely related to and, the latter of which used χ 2 tests to find phrases most associated with ideology as proxied by the language of U.S. Congresspersons.
We improve on this methodology by accounting for ideological word choice within topics and incorporating an ensemble approach that increases predictive accuracy.
We also motivate the need to adjust for topics even if doing so does not improve accuracy (although it does in this case).
We further provide evidence that fully unsupervised methods () may encounter difficulties learning latent ideological aspects when those aspects are not first order in the data.
Our algorithm is able to correctly predict the ideology of 69.2% of economists in our data purely from their academic output.
We also show that our predictions generalize and are predictors of responses by a panel of top economists on issues of economic importance.
Ina companion paper (), we further show that predicted ideologies are significantly correlated to economists' research findings.
The latter result shows the relevance and applicability of these tools beyond the task of ideology extraction.
